moves.1. d4: A beautiful London. I hardly believed it. Specially after losing a game with easy19 in the same tournament, in which I played very, very badly. With this game, I think I mantain the balance... blitzkov will have another chance to crush me, anyway :-)
moves.1... Nf6 2. Bf4 d5 3. Nf3 e6 4. e3: When black plays e6, h3 is not really necessary anymore. I like h3 because it supports g4-g5, a standard attack.
moves.4... Bd6 5. Ne5: Once Nf6 is played, this knight cannot be kicked anymore - or not that easily.
moves.5... O-O: A common response is Nh5, to which I'll go Bg3, and if NxB, hxN, I get a free semiopen column.
moves.6. Nd2: Better than Nc3, because I want to restrict black's dsb movements. If ever Bb4, c3.
moves.6... Nbd7: Black can take the N, but only at the cost of his dsb. And now black cannot play Nh5 anymore.
moves.7. Qf3: !? An antinatural move. Another chance is g4 at once. No advantage, but white is where it is supposed to be: attacking.
moves.7... Qe7: It seems a normal move, but black "had" to play c5, in order to open his position and activate his pieces.
moves.8. Bd3: Another gun over the black kingside.
moves.8... c6:
Dubious, I'd say. Black wants a solid position, but his lsb stays inactive. I'm already thinking on sacrifices (it doesn't work for a win... still:

moves.10. Bg5: Much better than Bh6, IMO. Now black is cramped, since it cannot exchange without losing a piece. There are a lot of variations, but the main point is that Nf6 is pinned.
moves.10... Kh8: Probably seeking for h6. I think black should have tried Qb4 at once. If I go NxN, NxN; Qh3, f5 and my attack vanishes. (Not BxN because of Qh4, and black cannot defend the king's position).
moves.11. O-O-O: After some calculation, I decided that there was no reason for hurry, since if I don't exchange pieces, black is cramped.
moves.11... a5: I feared c5. This is only a lost tempo, since my pressure against the kingside becomes now stronger, now.
moves.12. f4: Again, I had to be patient. This makes my e5 knight free to move. The point of all my attack is to avoid a black knight to be on f6, so I can attack h7. If black exchanges now, in addition to the threat on the pinned knight, I can open the f semicolumn. Anyway, Nh5, trying a queen's exchange, fails because my bishop, after BxQe7, Nh5xQg3, hxNg3, threats the black Rook.
moves.12... c5: At last, but a move too late.
moves.13. Qh4: Of course, if h6 at some point, I would have played h4, since hxB, hxg5+ was deadly for black.
moves.13... c4: I expected this, but my attack is ready to spring.
moves.15. Nxd7: The only correct move to win, IMO. I analyzed Nxf7+, too, but after RxN, Bg6+, Kg8, I have to save two pieces and I have no mate.
moves.15... cxb2+: Or cxNd2, it would have been the same.
moves.16. Kb1: Of course I don't fall for Kxb2.
moves.17... Kg8 18. Bxf6: An mate the next, whatever black does. I guess black has other defences, but how much should we go back to find it?
